content.title: Klippel-Trenaunay Syndrome
content.definition: Combined capillary-lymphatic-venous malformation (CLVM) characterized by the classic triad of capillary malformation (port-wine stain), varicose veins or venous malformations, and soft tissue/bone hypertrophy of an affected limb. Absence of arteriovenous shunting distinguishes it from Parkes Weber syndrome.

capillary_malformation.location: Typically lateral aspect of affected limb

types: Lateral embryonic vein (marginal vein of Servelle)

other: Bleeding from GI tract or GU tract

symptoms: Pain and heaviness in affected limb

imaging.duplex_ultrasound: Initial assessment of venous anatomy, marginal vein
imaging.mri_mrv: Extent of malformation, deep venous anatomy

content.statement: Klippel-Trenaunay Syndrome is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Vascular-Malformations that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Klippel-Trenaunay Syndrome.

learning_objectives: Recognize the classic triad of Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome
Differentiate from Parkes Weber syndrome (no AV shunting in KTS)
clinical_pearls: KTS = NO arteriovenous shunting; Parkes Weber = arteriovenous shunting (this is the key difference)
Marginal vein of Servelle is a persistent lateral embryonic vein - present in 70%
ALWAYS confirm deep venous patency before any ablative treatment
Compression therapy is the cornerstone of management
PIK3CA mutations link KTS to CLOVES and other overgrowth syndromes
common_misconceptions: Misconception: KTS and Parkes Weber are the same - Reality: PW has high-flow AV shunting

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
